newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - June 12.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - June 12.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Corporate advisers to the Telstra float are pressuring the telecommunications company to write down the value of its broadband cable network by up to A$1 billion, which would result in a large, one-off abnormal loss, but considered an essential "clearing he decks exercise". Page 1.

A new study for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, prepared by its East Asia Analytical Unit, warns Australian companies risk missing lucrative opportunities in Japan because they still believe it is a market that is too difficult to succeed in. The study showed there are only 60 Australian companies involved in Japan, compared to more than 200 involved in China. Page 1.

General Motors-Holden Automotive managing director and chairman Jim Wiemels said yesterday the value of the company's car and engine exports should lift to A$1 billion by the year 2000, and as much as A$100 million a year is expected to be earned in fees in its role as the designated GM design and engineering centre for the Asian and Pacific markets. Page 23.

In moves announced to the Australian Stock Exchange yesterday, Associated World Investments Pty Ltd, which is associated with Len Ainsworth, is under pressure from Aristocrat Leisure Ltd to sell 200,000 shares acquired in the poker machine giant in the pat nine months. Page 23.

Food industry analysts predicted yesterday it was more likely Goodman Fielder Ltd would offer to buy individual yeast assets from Burns, Philp & Co Ltd than make a full takeover of the troubled food company. A full takeover was not expected while Burns Pilp tried to sell its
herbs and spices businesses. Page 24.

CSR Ltd managing director Geoff Kells said in the CSR annual report released yesterday the building materials group promises investors to deliver a rise in earnings in the current year on the back of improving markets and continued restructuring. Kells says he believes the company is well-placed to expect better results in 1997-98. Page 25.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Epic Energy has defeated bidders including New South Wales-based AGL and United States-owned gas pipeline group PGT Australia to win an essential contract to transport gas to the proposed A$1.4 billion Mid West Iron & Steel project in Western Australia. The contract is valued at around A$450 million and is one of the largest of its kind in Australia. Page 19.

A new Federal Government study, A New Japan? Change in Asia's Megamarket, released yesterday by the East Asia analytical unit claims Japan is an easier market to crack for Australian companies than new emerging markets such as China, Vietnam or Indonesia, because of significant changes in the past 10 years. Page 19.

Following two years of strong growth the in Australian telecommunications market, leading discount telephone operator Worldxchange is planning to list on the stock exchange. Analysts believe the move by the United States-based company
will see it valued at more than A$100 million. Page 19.

In a bid to win a directors' recommendation, Sipa Resources International NL hopes to announce today an extension into the new financial year of its takeover offer for Arcadia Minerals NL. Arcadia directors said yesterday the takeover would be recommended to shareholders if the option was given to accept in either this financial year or the next. Page 20.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resources Economics revealed yesterday Australia's mineral export earnings fell 1.3 per cent to A$8.41 billion during the March quarter, the lowest result since the same period in 1996. The results come despite gnerally higher export prices. Page 21.

BHP's Ok Tedi copper-gold mine in Papua New Guinea has had its mill halved in response to the El Nino weather pattern, which has dramatically halted concentrate shipments. One of the two SAG mills at the Folomian ore treatment plant has been shut down, ad management will decided today if a further
cut in production is required. Page 21.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

The Australian Bureau of Statistics national accounts figures show Sydney has benefited from the boom in private and public construction resulting from 2000 Olympics preparations, with non-residential construction A$530 million higher during the March quater this year compared with the same period last year. Page 29.

Despite a draft ruling yesterday by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission that will see telecommunications service providers paying 40 per cent less to connect to Telstra's network after deregulation on July 1, the fight between the service poviders and the telecommunications giant over billing appears to be escalating. Page 29.

In a further development from within Aristocrat Leisure, which has been pressured by controversies since it listed last year, the company looks to be bowing to pressure from gaming authorities around the world, and is ousting Len Ainsworth, of
the foundin Ainsworth family, from any residual involvement. Page 29.

Addressing an Australian Business in Europe lunch in London yesterday, Westpac chief executive Bob Joss said in the wake of the Wallis inquiry into Australia's financial system, it was highly unlikely banks or insurance companies would merge, or foreign banks would take over Australian banks. Page 31.

In an attempt to attract and retain rural customers, the National Australia Bank will create 66 rural and provincial business banking centres which will operate from established branches in major regional centres. The move will cost about A$15 million, ad is part of a strategic shift in NAB's rural efforts. Page 31.

Sources close to Foxtel, the cable joint venture between Telstra and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, have indicated the company may argue to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission that a deal between its pay-TV rivals Australis Media
and Optus Vison would be anti-competitive. Page 31.
THE AGE

Following figures which show Australia's three largest private insurers suffered a 117 per cent rise in claims for delinquent loans in 1996, Commercial Union Australia Mortgage Insurance Corp general manager Richard Nott says there is no doubt the quality of lending has declined, as more borrowers are defaulting on their home loans. Page C1.

Aristocrat Leisure is hoping to restructure its board so that a majority of directors are independent of the controlling Ainsworth family, following pressure from the New South Wales Casino Control Authority. Aristocrat hopes to oust Len Ainsworth from any residual involvement, and force Associated World Investments, which is controlled by Ainsworth, to sell its existing 205,000 shares. Page C1.

Northgate Communications went one step further to becoming Australia's third main telecommunications carrier yesterday when it announced it was in advanced negotiations to build its second regional cable network in Kalgoorlie. The possible joint venture partner would be AlintaGas. Page C1.

A Federal Government report argues Australia is missing out on huge market opportunities in Japan because of misconceived ideas that the Japanese market is either too closed or too difficult to work in. The report, prepared by the Department of Foreign Afairs, believes Japan's booming import markets cannot
be ignored. Page C1.

Springsand Investments will seek orders and damages against Country Road in the Practice Court today, claiming the retail chain has broken a long-term lease on its former headquarters, owned by the head of Springsand, Solomon Lew, and his family. The lawsit continues a war between Lew and Country Road that began earlier this year when Lew and his son emerged as hostile shareholders. Page C3.

ANZ Bank has overcome objections from the Department of Health and Family Services that its new health insurance-linked Gold Mastercard breached the community rating principles set out in the National Health Act by offering discounts to a select group. Th bank will extend the offer to holders of ANZ's basic freedays MasterCard to ensure those who do not qualify for a gold card can still access the scheme. Page C3.
